Column Comment.0: SEISMIC SET SUBTYPE: The seismic set type column is used to enforce arelationship between the SEIS SET supertype and its valid sub types. Values for thiscolumn must be the name of the table that is the valid sub type for this row of data.Validentries include SEIS_LINE, SEIS_SEGMENT, SEIS_SURVEY, SEIS_PLAN,SEIS_WELL, SEIS_PROC_SET, SEIS_INTERP_SET or SEIS_3D.
Column Comment.1: SEISMIC INTERPRETATION SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the set ofseismic data that is processed. This set may be derived from one or more otherseismic sets.
Column Comment.2: SURFACE ID: unique identifier for the interpreted surface.
Column Comment.3: SEISMIC PICK ID: Unique identifier for the seismic pick
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: BIN GRID ID: Primary unique identifier for Bin grid.
Column Comment.6: BIN POINT ID: Unique identifier for the Bin Point.
Column Comment.7: SEISMIC SET: A seismic set is a super type of various types of seismic collections.
Column Comment.8: SEISMIC SET SUBTYPE: The seismic set type column is used to enforce arelationship between the SEIS SET supertype and its valid sub types. Values for thiscolumn must be the name of the table that is the valid sub type for this row of data.Valid entries include SEIS_LINE, SEIS_SEGMENT, SEIS_SURVEY, SEIS_PLAN,SEIS_WELL, SEIS_PROC_SET, SEIS_INTERP_SET or SEIS_3D.
Column Comment.9: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.10: DATE FORMAT DESCRIPTION: Use this column to define the level of precision inthe DATE format colums, such as YYYY, or YYYQQ, or YYYYMM or YYYYMMDD
Column Comment.11: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.13: INTERPRETATION TYPE: the type of interpretation, such as time, depth, amplitude,shifts etc.
Column Comment.14: PICK DEPTH: The vertical depth at which this pick was made.
Column Comment.16: PICK DESCRIPTION: Description of the pick, such as the type of unconformity thatwas picked.
Column Comment.17: SEISMIC PICK METHOD: The method that was used to make the seismic picks,such as automatic picking, manual picking, semi-automated picking etc.
Column Comment.18: PICK QUALIFIER: This reference table describes a qualifier used to describe aformation pick. For example not logged, missing, estimated or uncertain depth.
Column Comment.19: PICK QUALIFIER REASON: The reason that a qualifier was added for a pick, suchas poor data, faulting, erosion.
Column Comment.20: PICK QUALITY: the quality of or degree of confidence in the pick that was made,such as poor, uncertain, good, excellent.
Column Comment.21: PICK VERSION TYPE: the type of version of pick that is given in an interpretationtable, such as working, final, proposed etc.
Column Comment.22: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.23: PREFERRED PICK INDICATOR: a Y / N flag indicating whether this pick is thepreferred version to be used for calculations, reports, extraction etc.
Column Comment.24: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.25: SEISMIC PICK VALUE: value of the seismic pick
Column Comment.26: SEIS PICK VALUE ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE:
Column Comment.28: SEISMIC POINT ID: Unique identifier for each seismic point
Column Comment.29: SEISMIC SET: A seismic set is a super type of various types of seismic collections.
Column Comment.30: SEISMIC SET SUBTYPE: The seismic set type column is used to enforce arelationship between the SEIS SET supertype and its valid sub types. Values for thiscolumn must be the name of the table that is the valid sub type for this row ofdata.Valid entries include SEIS_LINE, SEIS_SEGMENT, SEIS_SURVEY,SEIS_PLAN, SEIS_WELL, SEIS_PROC_SET, SEIS_INTERP_SET or SEIS_3D.
Column Comment.31: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.32: TRACE IDENTIFIER: The number of the track that this pick is associated with.
Column Comment.33: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.34: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.35: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.36: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.37: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.38: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.39: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
